I think its something everyone should see, and although I felt a little uncomfortable intruding on peoples lives and entering their homes, no-one actually made me feel this way and Thando was happy to answer all our questions. I think it was more than I was uncomfortable knowing that some people in the world have so much when some have to survive on so little that made me uncomfortable, not the place itself. Thando even showed us his own home which was nice for us to see as it enabled us to know more about him as a person and felt much more personal and meaningful.So please continue to support ventures like this and buy some of the goods on offer when you visit (we bought a lovely salt and pepper set), you wont be disappointed.

Vamos Township Tours. This was one of the best experiences of my life. I highly recommend this tour to anyone and everyone, no matter where you come from. It was such a humbling experience that I will never forget. The people of the township were so welcoming and positive. Siviwe our tour guide was absolutely fantastic and I want to bring my family back over to visit the township of Langa.

Great experience in Cape Town. My wife and I took the half day township tour and really enjoyed it. Gladstone our guide was incredible. He lives in the main township (Langa) that we visited and was very open about life and experiences in the township. We toured a township museum, visited a house, classroom and walked/drove though the township. We had lunch at Mzoli's Meat a BBQ place in the Guguletu township near the airport. The food was very good. When in Langa, we also got to see them making the local beer. Our tour was with another family and Gladstone was great with the kids. He speaks the Xhosa language (with the clicks) and taught the kids a sentence with lots of clicks in it.It was a great experience. I really recommend you do a township tour when in the Cape Town area and Vamos does a fantastic job.

Must do tour. We'd researched many companies go on a Township tour. Vamos came out best as it was well reviewed and seemed to be based in Langa, used Langa guides and supported the Langa community. All this is true, we had a great time, our guide was Gladstone who brought Langa to life for us, even showing us the floor that he slept on until the age of 14 years !. No question was too difficult to answer and our 14yrs old boys found the experience humbling and very interesting. Lunch at Mzoli's to finish was amazing. A must do for any visitor to Cape Town !

Breathtaking. I've went on numerous tours all over the world some are not worth it, this was breathtaking. Siviwe was our guide, he is a very knowledgeable and a proud person. From the moment he collected us he tried to involve us by trying to speak their native tongue, gave a brief history of Langa and current economic and social issues they have. The tour we went on was a walking tour, we started off in the community centre that housed a pottery shop and art gallery. The walking tour is a tour primarily based on the different social classes they have. We started off on the lower class with a stop off at a Shebeen where they brewed Sorghum beer. We were shown the illegal trade in the community, importation of sheep heads and how it is prepared, to how the beer is brewed and fermented. From here we went to the middle class areas. He outlined the key differences from lower class areas. He brought us into his Aunts home (his home growing up)and showed a typical layout. Any issues they had growing up but just meeting the people in that area was a delight. For the upper class we just drove arround the area but typically it isn't much different from how we currently live. We stopped off at the Happy Feet Project and were shown where part of the money you paid for the tour was going. Finally for the finish we were brought to Mzoli's Meat for lunch in Gugulethu a different township. You select the meat you want and then it is cooked on the braai in front of you. It was the best food I've had in South Africa.Langa is a strange place from the outside it doesn't look much but the sense of pride they have about their town and beliefs instilled in them makes it a whole lot more. It does put your own life into perspective and hopefully it will make me a better person from it. Thanks for the tour Siviwe Mbinda and wish you the best in everything you do!

Tour was fantastic, thanks to Thando. Our tour guide Thando started the tour by saying we were his friends and visitors - rather than tourists - which really summed up the hospitality of Langa. Thando was very humble and knowledgable. He gave us a brief history before taking us to the different classes within Langa. The tour certainly opened our eyes to the sense of community apparent in Langa and just how positive everyone is. We also had the opportunity to see some pottery being made and play the drums. We bought some great pottery at the visitors centre. Jo Austin

Excellent Tour, Highly Recommended. Booked this tour at short notice having read the great review on TripAdvisor. Our bicycle tour was organised lead by Thando - what a lovely guy. He was very knowledgeable about the history of Langa Township, its people, its problems and its future. He was positive and optomistic, and we really enjoyed the tour. Thando also helped us get a taxi back to the city, and introduced us to some local crafts people. A highly recommended trip.

A really interesting and informative experience.. We wanted to take a township tour that would help us understand what the townships were really about, rather than a "drive-through" tour. Gladstone did not disappoint. He started by saying that we could ask anything we liked, and he would take nothing personally. As we walked through Langa with him our first impression was obviously of poverty but, as we saw more, we felt increasing respect for the sense of community and optimism there. We started to understand the huge challenges facing the people living with the aftermath of decades of neglect, but also the sense that things are improving at quite a pace. Gladstone also explained a lot about tribal customs and structures, and the impact of only allowing the men to move from the villages to the townships. He lives in Langa and we could sense his pride in the progress his community had achieved. We took the morning tour, which included a good lunch at Mzoli's which was an experience in itself. We'd definitely recommend Vamos.

Excellent eye-opening tour of Langa Township. During our 12-day trip to South Africa (from California), our family wanted to see more than animals and scenery. We had heard about opportunities to visit Langa Township during our stay in Cape Town, so we asked our South African travel consultant, WWS, and they put us in touch with Vamos Tours. We feel fortunate that our tour was led by Siviwe, the (co-)owner and founder of Vamos Tours. At our request, he started by explaining some of the history of South Africa, going back to the 17th century. He gave us a brief overview of the political and racial tensions that preceded the apartheid policy, which was officially imposed beginning in 1948. We learned about the ANC and the “Freedom Charter,” and how the racial, political and economic circumstances have evolved since Nelson Mandela was released from prison in 1990. He showed us poor neighborhoods, but also areas of Langa that are definitely middle class. We walked past ramshackle homes and small businesses, into a courtyard filled with both freshly-washed laundry and garbage strewn everywhere. (There is really no place to take the garbage, and no money to pay to have it picked up.) We chatted with inhabitants of a multi-family housing unit, where each 15X18 foot room houses a 3-5 member family. We were welcomed by little children who happily thronged about us while other children, members of Siviwe’s “Happy Feet” dance program, performed for us. Siviwe is a very intelligent, articulate and sincere young man who is proud of his community and its culture and eager to help visitors discover why. He told us how all the children are essentially raised by all the adults in their life – an uncle is also considered “Dad,” and all older adults are respected “aunties” and “uncles.” Siviwe repeated for us the five things children are taught that “make you wealthy on the inside:” 1. Don’t look down on someone who is struggling. 2. Don’t envy someone who has made it. 3. Don’t be racist. 4. Never let anger or hatred drive you and 5. Don’t beg. Pretty powerful rules to live by. And we had the impression that the self-confident children we encountered had already absorbed these important principles. Thank you, Vamos Tours, thank you, Siviwe, for a well-run, informative-yet-fun tour. It was the highlight of our 5 days in Cape Town!

Understanding the townships. Thando, our guide gave us a great tour which we took by bike. This is a great way to see the township Langa since by bike you can cover a large part of Langa. Thando made us understand how the township functions and learned us that it is not only the challenging housing you see along the highway but that there is also a middle class and a higher class population. We really got an insight in living here and the way safety is being assured amongst eachother. We highly recommend this tour with Vamos and advise you to take the bike.

An experience you shouldn't miss out on!. We visited the Langa township on an afternoon tour which included a trip to meet the kids and watch them perform at the Happy Feet Project. Our guide Gladstone was great, very informative and accommodating of our needs. We got to meet the local people, stopping to speak to them on the street in their homes and even in their pub where we got to taste their home brewed beer. The children we met around the township were lovely and we got to play a game of hopscotch with them which was great fun. Our last stop at the Happy Feet Project was one of the trip highlights, learning about the great work the organisation does and of course watching the fantastic performance from the kids. Would definitely recommend this tour!

Cape Town's Other Face. It was one of the most interesting experiences in South Africa so far. You are supposed to go there to know the reality of the country. We chose the cycling tour which brings you to most places in Langa. You will get in touch with residents and get the chance to learn about their circumstances and their stories. Thando - our great guide - even took us to his own house. As he is from Langa he really knows the area and the people. One might argue that going on a township tour is sort of voyeuristic. But the company's approach to show foreigners all aspects of the area and the fact that you can talk to the people helps to make a better understanding of this nation.

Fantastic. Tour was absolutely incredible. A truly once in a lifetime experience, the tour encompassed all areas of township life, from the poorest of the poor to the wealthier areas of the township. The tour guide was exceptional at providing information on township way-of-life, which helped an outsider, like myself, understand certain social dynamics that existed within the community. Everything from the beer-tasting to the spaza shops were educational and informative, and it was an experience that I will never forget. Thank you so much to Vamos for such a wonderful experience.

A heartwarming experience (:. My friends and i went on a cycling tour with Thando and agreed that it was one of our best experiences in the city. Thando was extremely accommodating and friendly and also offered us a glimpse into the rich community of the Langa township. The cycling tour also allowed us to cover most of the township in 2.5 hours and our only regrets were that we could not interact more with the people there. A must-do!

Fascinating township tour that climaxes in a rousing church service. Surely one of the most unexpected surprises on any trip to Cape Town would be the simple joys to be discovered in a township tour. Much like the favela tours in Rio de Janeiro, the Langa Township Tour run by the Vamos Company engendered an initial bit of hesitation on my part, but the avalanche of positive reviews on TripAdvisor made me soon realize that I would miss something special if I didn’t book it. Indeed I would because the tour is not an unrelenting and leering look at a people living in squalor and despair. Yes, there is plenty of poverty, but more importantly, there is a strong sense of community pride. Our guide was a local resident named Gladstone who took my partner and me around in his minivan. The tour begins with vibrant murals on an extended stone wall and continues to Gugas'Thebe, a multi-purpose cultural center that features local artists and musicians displaying their talent.We found our way into Gladstone’s old neighborhood where a fellow tour member picked up a big, see-through plastic bag filled with little bags of chips which brought out dozens of children in the rain. We walked through the maze of shantytown shacks, and while an occasional dead rat showed up in our path, we never felt a sense of dread no matter how spartan the conditions appeared to be. In fact, we were welcomed warmly into one shack where a young woman explained how she went to college and journeyed to San Francisco on a student exchange program. We ended up attending a Sunday church service at the Langa Christian Church where we were treated to a two-hour, roof-raising performance of gospel music and sermons. It honestly felt more like East Oakland than South Africa, but it was truly inspirational. Our tour ended with lunch at the home of a woman who rents out her bedrooms to backpackers. She served a spicy beef stew over rice that was quite delicious. The tour costs R 500 per person (or less than $50). This was a most worthwhile tour that I strongly recommend.

Amazing!. Truly a once in a lifetime experience. My wife and I came here on our honeymoon, having booked last minute. We wouldn't trade the experience for anything. Gladstone was an amazing tour guide.

Amazing!!!! The Real Cape Town Experience. My Wife and I took this tour after doing much of the the Vineyards and the usual tours around the beaches. We were so glad that other reviewers shared that Vamos guides are terrific and the Langa Township visit is a must do! It focuses on the history the tribes the culture and also what they have that keeps them together - thier communitiy. They are proud people and more than welcoming to have you visit. This is not a tour that your supposed to go and look down upon them - but actually you copme out with a heartening experience that most things in the western world are materilaistic and actually most of their way of life is centred about communication and enjoyment of life.. You will meet a wide variety of people from entrepreneurs who demonstrate the true meaning of small businesses to family members and children enjoying life and caring for each other. They have a strong sense of who they are and they know that they are not the weathliest people in Cape Town and by no way am I discounting that the poverty is profound but the spirit of the people in this Township is AMAZING. If you choose this tour, then choose Vamos. The visit to the community was intimate and Siviwe, our wonderful "Langa ambassador" was passionate and ver knowledgable about life in Langa and South Africa. We saw local businesses, homes, a cultural center with a chance to buy art and craft from Africa that is 25% of the price than you will have at the airport and belive me - a lot better You are safe when you are with Vamos and Siviwe as he knows everbody in the Township and everybody knows him. Amazing day. We loved it.

You need to go!. In my opinion, no trip to South Africa would be complete without getting a sense of township life. Siviwe did an excellent job of giving us a personal, balanced, and unsensationalized view of day-to-day life in a township. Vamos does a nice job with small group sizes and transfer from local hotels. Garth was very responsive helping us plan our visit. Take the option to go to Mzoli's for lunch. Excellent braai and you get to see a bit of other townships. Bring cash to pay for the tour and gratuity, plus a little extra to help support the economy at the cultural center, where there are high quality locally made crafts and artwork available.

Do.This.Visit!. I was pretty nervous about taking this tour after everything I read about how unsafe the townships are. I am so glad that other reviewers shared that Vamos guides are terrific and the Langa Township visit is a must do! It would be easy to focus on what the people living in Langa don't have - but instead I will focus on what they do have. They are a community. They are entrepreneurs who demonstrate the true meaning of small business. They have a strong sense of who they are and what it means to be from Langa. I'm not discounting the fact that the poverty is profound here, but the spirit of the people in this Township is anything but poor. More about Vamos. You need to choose this company. The visit to the community was intimate and Siviwe, our wonderful "Langa ambassador" was passionate and ver knowledgable about life in Langa and South Africa. We saw local businesses, homes, a cultural center (bring some cash - you will want to shop), and finished the visit with a delicious BBQ at Mzolis. For those of you who are like me...a little worried about being safe...do not worry! You are safe when you are with Vamos. Amazing day. We loved it.

Bicycle Tour with Thando is a Must!. What stands out to me the most from visiting Cape Town for the first time is doing a bike tour in the Langa township with Thando as our guide. While he led us through the community on bicycles, we realized that what was supposed to be a two hour tour extended into three hours, and we could have easily spent much more time there. We met Simon, a local artist with an array of handmade paintings, jewelry, journals, and other trinkets for sale, and by purchasing them, you know you are directly supporting the township. We did the tour on a Saturday; had we visited on a weekday, we may have seen the Happy Feet Youth Project. Thank you, Thando, for a truly memorable experience.

Do Not Skip This!. With so much to do in Cape Town, it's easy to choose one activity in lieu of another, based on time constraints. However, a Langa tour should truly not be missed. I must emphasize doing this tour with Thando as your guide; he was informative, compassionate, and I could tell he was truly an activist within the community. When I visit Cape Town again in the future, I will surely be returning to Langa and contacting Thando. The bike tour was a good choice for us (even though I hadn't ridden a bike in over 15+ years!), because you can definitely cover more ground. The only thing we wish we could have done differently was perhaps visiting during a weekday, when we might have visited a classroom and saw the Happy Feet Youth Project!

Good decision. Gladstone picked us up in a comfortable minivan and showed us life in Langa. I as well as other reviewers went there based on previous reviews and am glad I did. Other than maybe spending a little too much time at the local Sunday church service, the tour was excellent and made more personal done by people who live there, and hats off to your business model Siviwe, who saw an opportunity to construct a business that shows life in an area that so many visitors are uncomfortable with. Good luck to all of you and thanks for sharing your life with all of us.

okay to get a flavor. For anybody who has been inside Township before in South Africa it's worth the time and money. Our guide was and is very passionate about the Tour, if you can separate the sarcasm from his enthusiasm you'll be in good shape.You can expect to see how the Black South Africans live in the Townships especially the Langa one. You will see how much trash is accumulated while many hang around felling sorry and badly done by.The new homes look very spacious and very well constructed and it would interesting to see how they look in 5 years time.I remember the Aussie Aborigines going into simular homes and how they looked inside a year.I hope that the new residents look after new houses inside the best country in the world, South Africa.

Must see in Capetown. A visit to Capetown is not complete without seeing the townships, and the Vamos tour is great. Siviwe guided us around, and he just knows everyone around, having grown and still living in the township. I saw some reviews of people complaining about the hypocrisy of visiting a township. I would say the opposite. Only after being there you can begin to understand South Africa and the Apartheid.

A most wonderful decision. I wasn't sure if going in a township tour was the right thing to do but coming from Australia we have little information on the townships within South Africa so we as a family decided this was the only way to find out more. We are so very pleased that we did. Siviwe was our tour guide and is a remarkable young man. How special it was to have someone that lived within the township take us around and explain the history and current challenges of the people that were within his community. It was the best way for us to provide a little bit of support to a South African township and I strongly encourage everyone to do this tour as a way of helping a remarkable and truly special young man create a business and give back to his community. Good luck Siviwe and thank you for a delightful and thought provoking day.

Highly recommended tour!!. A trip to Cape Town would be missing an enormously important and genuinely thought provoking experience if you missed out on a township tour. We booked Vamos on the power of their trip advisor rating and we were not disappointed. We were picked up by our guide Gladstone at our hotel in a comfortable modern 'minivan' before collecting another couple on our way to the township of Langa. I have to say it started a little slowly and initially I had my doubts but it was building a picture and setting the 'story' in some context. From beginning to end it was interesting, sad, uplifting and thought provoking. You'll get a chance to see and feel everything you imagine - be prepared to be moved! You'll be amazed by the positivity of people living in such difficult circumstances and the pride they show in their country, each other and everything they do.Thanks so much Gladstone, you're a gentleman and I look forward to seeing your home in 'Beverly Hills' one day! ;-)

Really great tour given by a local resident. They pick you up from your hotel in a comfortable air conditioned minibus and drive you to a township (in my case, it was Langa). The driver and tour guide are the same person and is a local resident of the township. He taught us a few words in Xhosa on the way, and even sang a song in his native language. The tour itself includes a lot of walking and you feel quite safe when you are with a local guide. I tried the gospel tour which included a 10-15 minute stop at a local Baptist church. The energy there was amazing! People are singing and dancing. Tour eventually ends at a local house where they cook for you. Food was great and host was very hospitable. The township itself is strikingly different from Cape Town. You see how people live there, in what bad conditions... And you visit a few local houses. Overall, it was a great experience. Highly recommended.

Do this!. For those who are not into reading lengthy reviews I will summarize this: Contact them and do this.If you would like to know more details: We contacted Vamos tours through e-mail and they were very helpful and friendly and we booked a private half-day tour on rather short notice. Siviwe picked us up from our B&B and we drove to Langa township in his van. On the way he already gave us some background information about the townships and their development in general. We then had a short look at the community center before we started our walk through the township. During our tour Siviwe explained us more about the daily lives of the residents and he answered all the questions we had. We went into a bar and a true micro-brewery where we met other people from the township who told us about their lives an customs. Also we were invited into the homes of some residents and met some of Siviwe's friends. When we asked for a stop to look closer at a certain street that was no problem and we were shown around kindly again. The tour ended with a visit of the youth project Siviwe and the other guides run in the township where we had the chance to watch a dance invented, studied and performed by the kids taking part in the project.For us this was a great day and a unique experience. I cannot image that there are better township tours than this and I will do it again if I come back to Cape Town.I would like to end this review with paying respect to Siviwe who is not only the co-founder of Vamos Tours and as such a successful entrepreneur - which in itself is a difficult challenge as anyone who has ever founded a company knows. He also did this working his way up from the township himself making this an even greater achievement and he is paying back the community by running a project for the youngest in the township where they can develop their talents and interests. I pay him my deepest respect for all this. Big up!

Lange a great place to live. Our guide Gladstone introduced us to so many different friends in his community who made us really welcome. We could see how challenging life is for many of the residents, but also how strong the community is and how new housing projects, sport & art activities and business all contribute to make it a very positive place. Such a refreshing change from the glitzy capitalism of the city centre.

Unforgettable. This is a trip all visitors to Cape Town should take to get a balanced view of the city and to get an understanding of the people and their History. We could not have had a better guide than Siviwe and we left with the greatest respect for him and his people.

Best township visit company in CPT. Our host Siviwe was gracious, professional & personable who showed us a very special place. An amazing experience led by someone who knows many in the community personally and was willing to share much of his life experience. Our visit to Langa was one of the best things we did in Cape Town and Siviwe taught us much during our 4-hour visit. We were the only people with him and we were really able to interact with and learn more about the township and its residents. I highly recommend Vamos for anyone considering a visit to Langa.

To briefly experience the reality of South Africa.... You must visit a township. The V&A Waterfront, while a nice tourist destination, is very sterile. My wife and I were in Cape Town for a week (and I stayed an additional week for a conference). We wanted to see one of the surrounding townships first hand to get a sense, if only for a brief moment, of how people really live outside the city.I e-mailed with Vamos to set up our tour. Our guide was Gladstone, who had grown up in Langa Township; in fact, he was able to take us to his old building and the small trailer he had purchased as a teenager. He was very knowledgeable, and pointed out to us details that we would not have otherwise noticed - such as, when the police drove by, there was a flurry of activity due to shop vendors hiding their unlicensed alcohol inventory!I think Vamos tries to keep their tours small. We did encounter another tour group that was much larger as we were walking through Langa. Our group was just myself, my wife, and Gladstone. We felt very safe throughout Langa (in fact, safer than I feel at home in some areas!), although when we went to visit Gugulethu, Gladstone wanted us to stay in the car until we reached our lunch destination, Mzoli's.The entire trip was very informative and eye-opening, especially since we had really only seen the townships through car windows on our way into and out of Cape Town. If you have any interest, I would highly recommend making time for this excursion. As with most services in South Africa, for Westerners the prices are very reasonable or even a bargain.

Vamos township tour: highight of our visit to CT. This was simply one of the best things we did during our trip in SA, delivered way beyond our expectations and completed our experience. Siwiwe was great: honest, knowledgeable, a lot more than a tour guide. He lives and breathes Langa, and this is evident from his every word and move. We were lucky to be only 5 people (us, and a mother with two daughters) on the half day tour, that included transfer, a walking tour and a lunch at Mzoli's, one of the most famous braii eatery in SA. Very hands-on, interactive tour with no taboo questions. It was real, and there is so much to learn from Siwiwe and his people. We learned about Xhosa culture, South African history but above all, their attitude, and general way of thinking left a major mark on us, it is truly inspiring. Thank you very much for this lifetime memory, keep it going, and all the best to this great initiative.

Outstanding Tour With An Exceptional Tour Guide!. My family and I went on the Langa Township tour last September. The experience was far beyond amazing! Thanks to our tour guide Siviwe, we were introduced to the heart of South Africa. Siviwe's passion and love for his township and career were truly inspiring. We found ourselves speechless by his professionalism, knowledge, flawless English, social skills, and excellent approach to people. Siviwe guided us across the township, introducing us to the people, language, customs, foods, and spirit that define South African townships. His energy and enthusiasm kept us intrigued, amazed, and yearning to hear more throughout the entire time. Siviwe opened up to us and spoke truthfully, honestly, and zealously of his life in the township and the true meaning behind living in Langa. It is also essential to emphasize that At no point during the tour did we feel unsafe or anxious. Furthermore, Siviwe's tour even gave us an opportunity to socialize with the Langa residents and even join a local family during dinner preparation!Overall, choosing Vamos Langa Township Tours was the greatest decision we made during our visit to South Africa.In retrospect it was simply a flawless tour given by a skilled and exceptional guide. My family and I urge anyone who travels to the area to take part in this magnificent journey with Siviwe or any other member of the fantastic Vamos Team.

Stop! Yes, stop, look no further; you’ve found the right tour team. We’d trawled through TripAdvisor (and other portals) for an absolute age to find the right township tour. We didn’t want to be voyeurs, we didn’t want to tag along with a half-a-dozen other tourists. What we did want was a straightforward and honest guide who’d happily chat through the reality of South Africa’s past.Finally we came across Vamos Tours and liked their ‘vibe’. Garth was super-quick to respond to all of my questions and I was confident in their ability to provide what we were looking for.As the day approached, we got an email from Garth to say that our guide for the day would be Siviwe. We were also provided with his contact details etc. Siviwe turned up, bang on time, and introduced himself. It was at this point I knew we’d got the best guy. Smart, smiley, chatty and very, very cool. We’d struck gold here, I was sure! To make it even better was the fact that these tours are private, it was just me and my partner. Siviwe drove us towards the township and chatted along the way. No subjects were taboo and I learnt more in the first ten minutes speaking with him than on the previous ten days I had spent in SA.We arrived in the township and Siviwe turned the engine off and chatted for a good ten minutes about the history of SA (much, much more than you’ll ever get from a book). So compelling was his story that it brought tears to my eyes (I’m a bloke so I’d never properly cry, clearly) it made me smile, a little lumpy-throated again before ending on a high.We set off again and stopped off at a local craft/education centre where one of the ceramicists told us their goals and achievements. A proud guy. We could then take a look at some of the stuff on sale. But there was absolutely no pressure to buy, none. Because Siviwe had moved the (new, air-conditioned) van while we were in the centre, we were able to walk with him though the streets. He explained the goings on of the township (where he himself lives) and gave us the full low-down of how life really was. This wasn’t a ‘Disney’ tour. Everybody we passed were keen to smile and the kids all wanted to high-five us. To see their smiles was something else and affected me more than I could imagine. We continued through the streets (passing bigger groups who clearly couldn’t expect anything like we were experiencing) and took a look in some ‘hostels’, which housed numerous families. We then came across a bunch of kids who were enjoying a ‘kick-around’ with a ball that had seen much better days. I’d sort of expected this so I’d brought a few new decent footballs from London and pumped them up before lighting up lots of faces! This was something else and totally priceless. We then went on to a shack and spoke to one of the girls who was living there. Totally humble and 100% focused on being the best she could be by studying hard and refusing to feel sorry for herself. Finally, we then headed off to another township (handed a few more balls/lit up little faces) before going to M’zolis for one amazing Braii (our very first!) lunch.Throughout our few hours together I learnt heaps. I felt that Siviwe was more of a friend by the end of the trip and I have a huge amount of respect for him as a person, for what he does and for what he stands for.A totally priceless experience for very, very little money. Go, go, go Siviwe, you’re something else. Vamos tours rock!

Vamos should be your first choice for township tours. My colleague and I did the Vamos half-day gospel tour last August (sorry for writing the review so late, Siviwe) and we loved it. We got a wonderful guide, Siviwe, who lives in the township and really gave us an inside into how people think and feel and live. We visited the community center, walked around the township, ate a wonderful lunch in a home and got to see the Happy Feet kids. We cannot praise it enough.

Wonderful Bike Tour of Langa with our two children. We had a wonderful experience with our guide Thando who took us all over Langa Township on bikes. My two sons aged 12 and 10 loved the experience. Our 12 year old was a little nervous, he did not feel it was right to look at people in poverty, but he soon overcame that and really understood this was about transcending cultural divides and discovering commonalities between people regardless of wealth and background. Everyone was so friendly, and welcoming, it was fantastic. The boys got to help slice and dice some chips (fries) at an informal fish and chip shop, they loved the sheep head bit, and we all learned a huge amount. We visited several of Thando's friends and families in different parts of the township, so got to see a "middle class" area as well as the poorer shacks. Would highly recommend it. We got a taxi to the cultural center, was no problem at all. Felt safe throughout.

Real Life, Heartfelt Passion. The love of family, community and life came alive through the eyes and stories of our guide Siviwe. From the moment he picked us up at our hotel, until we returned, he shared his passion and showed us the real hearbeat of the Langa township. We visited the community center,talked with locals learning new skills and hugged small children playing in the streets. Siviwe knew most of the people we encountered and they graciously allowed us into their homes and businesses for an inside peek. As our tour was on a Sunday morning, we also had the special treat of attending the local church services. The congregation welcomed us and we enjoyed a very upbeat spiritual worship time.Our tour was concluded with a wonderful meal served in the beautiful home of one of locals.. Delicious meal and sharing of more hopes, dreams and traditions of the Langa township.An amazing, eye opening experience that should not be missed, Thank you Vamous!

An unforgettable and inspiring visit. "He's got the whole world in his hands", the children belted out on a bright, blue Sunday morning in the Langa township. The dismal buildings we saw from the highway transformed before our eyes as our guide, Siviwe, shared his community with us.You should not visit South Africa without going on a township tour with Vamos. Co-founder and guide, Siviwe, was inspirational, enlightening, informative, and downright fun to be around. Growing up in Langa, Siviwe led us on a visit of the home where he grew up, his neighborhood, and his community. This wasn't just a tour, it was a friendly visit. Siviwe gave us a full look into life in the township - he shared his vision for a bright future for the people of Langa, and we learned about the education, traditions, and culture of the supportive community. We had a chance to meet local artists, visit entrepreneurs, learn the "click" of Xhosa from a sweet child, clap to the upbeat music at Sunday church, and share a delicious home-cooked meal. The entire morning was moving and unforgettable.Vamos picked us up on time at our hotel in a beautiful, brand new van. The whole trip was coordinated beautifully, and Siviwe introduced us to all the people and children he knew along the way. We concluded that this one visit to Langa with Vamos and Siviwe will be etched in our hearts and minds longer than any other experience in Cape Town - the wine lands, Cape Point, Table Mountain. We laughed. We reflected. We soaked it all in. We identified with the mantra, "Wake up and do something for yourself" and we said, "Let's Go! (Vamos)"

The Best Way to Get an Understanding of Township Life. Sivewe is the best tour guide I have ever had. He is from Langa Township and knows everyone there. He really helps you see the township through the eyes of the people who live there, and he gives you great insight into their culture and way of life. With Sivewe, you do not feel like you are there as a tourist but as a guest. You will spend days afterward, reflecting on township life and every time you think of Sivewe, you will smile!

Awesome way to appreciate local life in Cape Town!. Nathi took my friends and I - a group of 8 girls - on the afternoon bicycle tour of Langa. Truthfully, I didn't know what to expect, but the tour far exceeded my expectations! Overall, it was a very eye-opening and impacting experience. I very much enjoyed learning about life in the township. Nathi was informative and passionate about his community. I am thankful we had the opportunity to see how the people lived. The people and children were very warm and welcoming. FYI, the children did not sell trinkets or ask for money - which is what I've experienced many times when visiting local villages in other countries in the world. The people seemed to genuinely enjoy tourists for the purposes of educating and enjoying their community. I highly recommend doing the bicycle tour; you will leave feeling appreciative of the little things and realization it's the people around you that matter the most!

Finally a Siviwe tour. I took the half day morning township tour with Vamos Tours and It was the best tour I ever had. Siviwe, our guide, is a proud Langa resident and he provided such an amazing and informational experience. I would say Langa is a town like no other, and you have to experience it on your own to understand the community and its people.

You have not see Cape Town unless you have done a Vamos Tour. I took 8 senior managers of Table Mountain Aerial Cableway on a full day tour with Siviwe Binde of Vamos Township Tours. The day was everything I wanted it to be, informative, real, insightful and just so eye opening for all concerned. It was an amazing experience - i feel privileged to have done it and sad that so many miss this opportunity. We took the cycling option which was great fun, ending with a huge plate of meat at Mzoli's which was just so tasty.We were safe and felt safe at all times.

Best township tour to date!. A canadian friend and me recently did one of Vamos' township tours. This was the third towhship tour I've attended, and must add that this one is highly recommended. The price is reasonable, the trip is filled with just enough valuable information, and the client's needs were attended to at all times.The lunch at Mzoli's (included in the price yes!) was a big treat!Not to be missed!

Don't miss the cycle tour of Langa Township. My tour was with Tahmdo and it was excellent. Biking was a great way to see the township, we were able to cover a lot of ground but also interact with the residents. Tahmdo knows a lot of people which I loved. He is a very authentic person. We stopped often to talk and even though I did not understand their conversations which were not in English, I felt very much a part of the place. I think this tour is one of the best things I have ever done. I felt completely safe. I feel like I experienced something few people get to experience. It really was incredible.

A Must Do Experience. Gladstone was a fabulous guide, teaching us Xhosa as well as explaining so much about the area, its residents and the challenges of the past and present. People have asked us if we felt unsafe, so I thought we should mention here that we felt 100% safe at all times. Langa is the oldest township with a very strong community culture. Crime levels are low as everyone knows everyone else and if anyone did do anything wrong, they'd be quickly reprimanded in their local way. The residents did seem to welcome us and Gladstone explained that this is because they want perceptions to chance and through educating as many tourists as possible, it helps offset the often inaccurate perceptions portrayed by the media. The 2.5 hour walking tour is not to be missed, it gives you a genuine insight into the people of SA that will certainly enhance your trip and if you're anything like us, the memory will last a lot longer than the time of the tour.

I have to admit that my township tour with Vamos was a couple of years ago and it is only now that I have got round to writing t. I have to admit that my township tour with Vamos was a couple of years ago and it is only now that I am writing a review! I apologise to Siviwe as I had promised to write one on my return from my holiday to Cape Town in 2010! Having had plenty of time to reflect, I can honestly say that this excursion was the most moving and memorable one I have had for many years. Siviwe started by explaining the history and gave us a really honest account of life in Langa before we arrived. We felt confident that we were safe and walked round the streets just chatting with the locals and asking questions. The highlight of the trip was watching the performance by Happy Feet Dance company in a small garage, this was really special as it was in Siviwe's own childhood neighbourhood, which was one of the most deprived in the township. The youngsters were clearly dedicated to putting on a good performance for the visitors and were even more excited to see Siviwe, who had just purchased a video recorder for the group, so they could watch their own performances. The tour is extremely good value, but any extra donations to the dance group are reinvested into the project to develop the children's skills and chances of improving their lives. I was just so impressed that Siviwe was able to show the youngsters in his own community that they could have a better life through hard work and initiative. If you you only do one tour in Cape Town.... Do this one!

Very good indeed, fascinating, informative, safe and good fun. Gladstone was an excellent guide who introduced to his community in Langa township with openness and good humour. After a tour of the community centre (and opportunities to buy local crafts - bring cash and change) we toured the former Pass Office, bought a bucket of maize beer to share with the regulars of a shebeen. We then walked through the streets to the hostel block where Gladstone lived when he first came to Langa as a young man, and briefly visited Silabulela school. We ended up with a welcome beer (it was very hot) at Mzolis in Gugulethu. We were very impressed by how friendly and positive people were. Thanks, Gladstone, this was a real eye opener and well worth the money and the time.

Good but missed out on some things we wanted to see. Our guide was from Langa and it was a good to learn and spend time in the townships. We took the 2.5 hrs walking tour of Langa. The guide was prompt in picking us up from the hotel and spoke about the history of Langa and his childhood. The clicks in his native language and the way they speak it was eye-opening. We enjoyed the tour but missed out on a few things we really wanted to see. For instance, we wanted to see the local medicine lady but we never did. We wanted this to be an interactive tour to interact with the people and kids, but we never got a chance to interact with anyone. In sum, it was a good tour!

This Is Real Cape Town!. If there was one tour I wanted to be sure to do with my 13 year old daughter, it was the Township Tour. Our day started with Garth Angus ( the chap who acknowledges the reviews) and who is a partner with Sivewe , who does the Township tour through Langa. The morning was really rainy and overcast so Garth adapted the city tour on the fly and essentially gave us a historical overview of South Africa , from the time it was discovered 500 years ago through the end or Apartheid. We spent time in the District Six Museum and Garth' s overview of the forced evacuation of this area was fascinating. He is well spoken, intelligent and a really first rate guide. We then drove to Mzoli's for lunch. We loved the authentic experience and the braii was fabulous ! Not a great spot if you are vegetarian though. There we met Sivewe and started our Township Tour . We walked through all areas, from those where the very nice homes are situated to the shacks. Sivewe talked throughout and provided such insight into life in the Townships. ( He has no intention if leaving, by the way, notwithstanding the success of his business). Can there be a more memorable ( and valuable) experience for a child or teenager who takes so many things for granted? Although we never felt unsafe, incredibly, we were told less than 5 % of white South Africans have ever walked through a Township. If you doubt that, take your own informal poll. This tour is hire in price than many day long tours but worth it and more. Neither of us will soon forget this experience and I wish Sivewe's Happy Feet Project ( the concept of which he will explain) every successWhich he will

Engaging, intimate, insightful, amazing ... Don't Miss This!. Captivating 2 hour cycling tour of Langa followed by lunch at Mzoli's Meat Restaurant. Our tour guide was informative, friendly and fun. The tour started at the cultural entre where we played drums and perused the locals art goods. Siviwe (tour guide and owner) was extremely informative throughout the tour. it was fascinating to hear about his life in Langa and his success story. The people of Langa were delightful and friendly and the kids were adorable!The icing on the cake for this tour was lunch at Mzoli's ....tasty Braai in a special sauce served with a salsa and maize....and beer of course! Don't miss this.....no doubt it will remain the highlight of our trip to Cape Town!

Inspiring. My colleague and I were in Cape Town for the Mining Inbaba conference and, after a week of corporate schmoozing, wine tours etc. wanted to do something which showed us another side of South Africa - this proved the highlight of our stay. A moving, inspiring and incredibly informative tour which left us both enlightened and encouraged about the future of South Africa. Siviwe is a delight - warm, intelligent and eager to share all and everything you want to know. Cannot recommend this tour highly enough - go, learn, enjoy and walk away with a smile.

Excellent tour for families, Siviwe is a truely amazing individual and tour guide!. Siviwe did a great job in guiding us through Langa township as well as his own success story. Our kids (10 & 11) and we learnt so much about the history of townships and saw first hand how different families lived. What made a huge difference was the factt that Siviwe grew up at Langa and is still a very proud resident. At the end he also showed us his own youth project, where kids become part of a dance group similar to stomp. All in all fantastic value for money and the best tour we have done in a long time!

Excellent insight into township life. I visited Langa with a small group and we were shown round by Sivewe who was very interesting and informative , being a resident himself. We were picked up and dropped back to our hotel and the whole visit was one of the highlights of my trip. As the other reviewers have said - Go, you won't regret it!

Langa township tour. Our tour of Langa with Siviwe was more than excellent. We were made to feel very welcome--more like guests than tourists. Siviwe's love and pride for the place he grew up in was very obvious. He showed us everything---the good and the bad, answered all of our questions, and helped us understand the history, even waited as we had several stops to take pictures of the children who would run up to us, hold our hands and give us lots of hugs.We wish him all the best, especially with the Happy Feet gumboot dancers. We were lucky to see them perform.We were also very grateful that Siviwe delivered my husband's hat, which he left in the van, to our hotel the next day. We didn't even ask him for it--very thoughtful!

Interesting perspectives. We did a 2.5 hr walking tour of Langa with Gladstone who is a local resident. My husband and I live in Cape Town and have been into the townships before but it is quite another experience being taken around on foot by a local. the townships remind us of the strength of human spirit and our collective responsibility to in some way give back to the community if we are lucky enough to not be living in a shack.Gladstone was an informative and pleasant guide. He spoke slowly for my German family and allowed us plenty of time to ask questions and do translations for the children. His relationship with the people we visited made us feel like guests rather than tourists.While chatting to Gladstone at the end of the tour I realised that although certain standard routes are covered, some 'attractions' like shebeens, sangomas (medicine woman), churches etc are visited on request. We only did a short walking tour (which was about the extent that 3 children between 8 and 10 years could cope with!) but it seems to be possible to customise the route to a certain extent. I would recommend discussing your requirements before you book and set off.

Eye-opening township tour. We did a fascinating Langa township tour with Nathi, our great guide. It was a real eye-opener to see how people live in the township, often in desperate poverty but still maintaining a sense of real community. We had the opportunity to learn about the history of townships first hand from Nathi who grew up in Langa and still lives there. He was very informative and the morning passed very quickly. Our private tour included a colourful visit to a Baptist church where we were part of a memorable gospel service. Our favourite stop (especially for our 12 year old daughter) was at Happy Feet, a community project where young children express themselves through dance (in gumboots!!) Remember to take sweets, pencils etc to give to the children. It was a lovely experience. We took loads of photos and video and everyone we met was happy to pose. We shall be posting lots of photos back to Nathi to distribute. It was a great experience, especially with older children who will probably learn more about township life from a few hours with Nathi than reading any number of books. Just do the tour, learn something and support the people of the township!

Township Tour by Bicycle. Our guide Nati picked us up in town for a transfer by minibus to his township of Langa where we were given sturdy commuter bikes and off we went. Nati showed us his township - warts and all. Some bits were confronting (such as the cramped and ramshackle living quarters), some facts were surprising (such as the contrast of the neat and solid houses just a street away from abject poverty - people growing up in townships don't leave their cultural group behind, just because they are able to make a better living), and some parts were really entertaining (like the kids doing a rythmical dance routine wearing gum boots). We were able to interact with people, and stop whenever we saw something interesting or when we had a question. Nati is very knowledgeable and has a great sense of humour and is passionate about his fellow citizens in general and the children of the township in particular. The terrain is flat and the pace is slow, so anyone who can ride a bike will easily manage.

Vamos township tour. We too were unsure about taking a township tour but Sivewe made us feel very comfortable. He was passionate about Langa and where he grew up. We felt like we saw the real Langa. A very worthwhile tour. I won't forget it.

Great township tour with Tandu!!. WE had a real interesting bike tour through the Langa township, Tandu showed us every corner of it, the better areas and the shags...We felt every time save and saw shags from inside and the inofficial markets and the sheep head cooking....real strange!

An experience that we won't forget!. When in Capetown in April 2012 we took at walking tour of Langer Township with Siviwe, an enthusiastic and delightful young man. He took us to a skills training workshop, a sheebeen, hostel accomadation, shanty accomodations and introduced us to his fellow residents of Langer. And whilst walking and driving us back to our hotel told us of his experiences of coming to Langer from his village as a 10 year old as well as enlightening us with much information on pre and post Apartheid South Africa.He invited us to a performance of Gumboot dancing with Happy Feet the next day. What an exciting and energising experience that was.It was such a joy to meet a young man so committed to representing his township and it's history!!Helen and Ernst Wirtz, Melbourne Australia

Don't miss this!. We were initially unsure about taking a township tour as we didn't want to seem like Aussie sticky beaks peering into peoples lives BUT after discussing with our accommodaiton provider we were referred to Sivewe at Vamos Tours and were thrilled to be supporting a very special young man and his township in this growing industry! We did a walking tour through Langa followed by some drive throughs of other townships and lunch at the famous Mazoli! We were very lucky to have Sivewe to ourselves on the day we chose (given it was low tourist season) and we were so impressed by this gentle, eloquent, clever and driven young man! It is hard to explain just how rewarded we were by this tour - it is beyond what you see, or what you do during your time with Sivewe, which was all facinating (so foreign) and educational - but more about the feeling of hope and positivity which we were left with. After two weeks of being shocked and confused by the living conditions we were seeing from "outside" the townships, we left Cape Town with a greater cultural understanding than could have been possible without this experience. Good luck with building your business Sivewe - we will certainly be recommending your experience to our family and friends.

One of best things to do in South Africa!!!!. This tour was one of the best things we did during our 3 week stay in South Africa! It is a real eye-opener about how the former oppressed people in South Africa feel and act.Seeing how the people live in the township and pushing to get a better life by working hard and investing into their children was very impressive.We had really open discussion with our tour guide about politics, South African history but as well as sports. The small group with only two of us and the guide was perfect. We were able to directly feel his enthusiasm about the opportunities his community has after the apartheid.However it has always been fun and we were able to see so many differrent place and meet with great people!We will always remember that day - our guide made us believe that South African people are very proud of their country and will have a great future!

An experience you will always remember. I can't say enough about this township tour. This was my first visit to Cape Town, and South Africa overall, and aside from playing with baby lion cubs (who wouldn't love that!), doing this tour was our most memorable and wonderful experience. Sivewe took us on a private cycling tour throughout Langa (lucky for us the rainy weather scared off the other patrons) and he shared a wealth of information with us about the township, the people, the history and the culture of the township. Probably the most memorable moment was when we were cycling by a local club (which was so small it could only really fit 10 people at best) and I insisted that we go in and I danced with some of the locals (not part of the official tour by any means). The locals thought the sight of this 34 year old white tourist dancing to their music was just hilarious (in a good way i hope) and we all had a great time. The performances of the happy feet children was also a highlight! They were all so friendly and passionate about their dancing it was inspiring. As for safety, I never ever felt like I was in danger and our car remained safe and sound outside the visitors centre for the entire duration of the tour. If you do this tour, I would definitely recommend you do the cycling tour. You can cover so much more ground than a walking tour and it was wonderful to be out in the open air interacting with the locals, seeing and hearing the vibe of the township. At one point we passed by another tour company whose tour consisted of a driver with the tourists sitting in the backseat of a car. They saw us on our bikes and you could see the instant jealousy in their eyes. If you are contemplating doing this tour and my advice to you is JUST DO IT! You won't be disappointed. Also I'd like to say that this is the first and only trip advisor review I have ever written. I don't usually tend to make the time to write reviews, but this is the first time in my life where I have felt so strongly about an experience, I had to share it.

take a Langa township tour with Vamos. You should definitely take this tour! My family (two kids, age 11 and 8) went on the half-day Vamos tour of Langa, and it was fantastic. It was eye-opening to go inside the shacks and hostels and see the living conditions of SA's many poor. It was an up-close social history lesson, and though shocking in many ways, it was an inspiration to see the commitment of our guide Sivewe, who coaches the township kids in awesome dancing and is very knowledgable about all aspects of township life. Definitely one of the most memorable experiences in our SA trip, and a balance to the sleek 'waterfront' side of Cape Town. Enjoy the braai experience at Mzoli's restaurant!

Great township tour. Went on a private township tour with Siviwe. Started with an incredible lunch at Mzoli's, then toured the township. Siviwe was incredibly knowledgable, passionate, and interesting. We learned a lot and my whole family agreed this was the best thing we did in Cape Town. Highly recommended

Absolutely inspirational. This was the highlight of two weeks in South Africa. We learnt so much about township life and were both humbled and uplifted by the whole experience. The tour was fascinating and the people we met - especially our guide Siviwe - were absolutely inspirational.

Genuine, interesting and eye-opening. Siviwe, the co-owner and our tour guide, is a really inspirational man. He took us on a long trip around his home town, allowing us to ask questions, meet people and see the positive side to his neighbourhood, as well as the challenges. A tour with him is a must-do activity for anyone in cape town, he is a really interesting guy and his tour was fantastic. He also does cycling tours!

Best tour guide in town. Thanks for a great tour today in the Langa Township! I´m sure you´re by far the best guide in the township. We can advise anyone who wants to have an understanding of how a township works to take contact with Vamos Tours!Tanks again // Team Sweden

An Experience you shouldn't miss!. This tour is of Langa Township, just 10-15 minutes drive from the V&A Waterfront, off the N2 at exit #12. If you are inquisitive, as we were, I would recommend the 2:30 pm starting time. In this fashion, you will experience and learn a lot about township life, meet the boys that do the gumboot dancing, see various businesses AND have loads of time for questions. Plan for about 2 & 1/2 hours of very easy biking. The nice thing about the bicycle tour, compared to the walking tour, is that you cover far more ground, thus obtaining a greater appreciation of the layout of the town.  Our guide was Nathi, very well spoken and willing to field any and all questions. I would encourage you to ask questions, it is a great way to learn, and really obtain some reality about life in South Africa.  I cannot say enough about this experience!

Fantastic Langa Township Tour with Siviwe!. Our family enjoyed and highly recommends a wonderful, educational Cape Town Langa township tour with Siviwe, co-owner of Vamos Tours. The tour was an excellent introduction to Cape Town and more broadly to South African history for both adults and our children, as young as 6 years old. We appreciated Siviwe's open perspective and the personal stories that he shared during the township tour. The visit to his Happy Feet project was a really nice addition for our kids, as they had a chance to meet township kids in a fun setting. The braai at Mzoli's was a very special close to a great morning. Highly recommended.

Great Tour - great people!!. There are so many ways of visiting a Township, over the last years we tried many of them...and for sure, the bycicle tour is the one to do!! It doesn't get any better than this, it was only us 3 and 2 guides - it was a very interessting and well organized tour. Our Guide (Nati?) was extremly informative and friendly. Besides, it is a eco friendly tour as well :)This is my first entry on Trip Advisor and I am happy to give Vamos the honour :)

Maybe the best tour ever.Memorable.Knowledgeable.Life changing.Fun.. It is six months later and the memory of the day I spent with Garth and Siviwe still stays with me, and my family still talks about it. It was everything a great tour should be - interesting, informative, well paced, different, and fun. We started the day with a history tour with Garth and the four of us had different levels of knowledge about So.Africa and yet Garth kept us all fascinated and we all learned much. He has an incredibly great - and fair - knowledge of this country's interesting past. And then Siviwe took over - taking us first for lunch in a township and then on a walking tour. What an infectious sense of delight this impressive young man has. He grew up in the township and still lives there and he gave us insights we probably would never have had. We ended the day dancing with the children of Happy Feet - Wow - touching, happy, great. We always felt entirely safe. My 18 year old niece who was entering college joined the African Studies club after this trip. I can not recommend Vamos highly enough. They are thorough pros.

The highlight of our Trip-if you do one tour Do THIS ONE. There are no words to describe this tour but I will try. Siviwe -our guide is inspiring, knowledgable and so passionate about his people and country. He not only showed us the townships but made us feel and understand. We laughed so much and it was such a positive experience. Our kids played with the children and did clapping games, we were invited in to peoples homes and businesses and we had the most AMAZING lunch. The best part was when we got to meet the children from his not for profit organization Happy Feet and see the kids perform for us. We truly loved it. We have been traveling around the world for the last 3.5 months with our kids (7 and 9) and this is one of the things that will stay with us forever. THIS IS THE TOUR TO DO if you visit cape town.

Wonderful Walking Tour. This is a brilliant way to spend 2.5 hours in Cape Town. We had just arrived in this vibrant and interesting city and Ursula's tour was a brilliant way to get an understanding of the historical context. Ursula is a fabulous guide and we thoroughly enjoyed the tour. If you can arrive 15 mins early the exhibition on diamonds and precious stones in the basement of Prins (where you meet and purchase tickets) is well worth doing. Thanks Ursula!

Great walking tour of Cape Town. This 2.5 hour walking tour is a leisurely and thoroughly enjoyable introduction to the history and geography of Cape Town. It is run by Ursula Stevens, who has lived in the city for over 30 years and is very knowledgable about its past and present. The tour covers all the major points of interest as well as more out of the way places that the average tourist may not get to see. This is a great way to start your stay in Cape Town.

Must do walking tour. We did a historical tour with Ursula around Cape Town. It was raining when we started but in no way dampened the tour. Ursula was so informative and entertained us as we walked around the points of interest. Well worth it if you have the time.
Cape Town Historic City Tour. Ursula was a great tour guide and walked us through many historical parts of Cape Town describing the evolution and painting pictures of what it looked like in the past.

A perfect tour. Went with our group of French teenagers from Reunion Island on a tour of Cape Town with Ursula. She loves her town, the history and the people who live in this beautiful city. We particularly enjoyed Bo-Kaap, we visited one of the Mosque, a first experience for us, the kids were attentive during the 2-hour tour and we were all impressed by her knowledge & her kindness. We ended this perfect tour at the flower market !

A tour with a friend!. We had a wonderful tour with Ursula today. It was like a visit with and old friend. She was knowledgable, pleasant and patient. It was very obvious she had the respect of many in the community which afforded us some 'behind the scenes' experiences. She shared that she has been giving these tours foe sixteen years, but it seemed as fresh as the first time to us. Many commented about her knowledge of the Cape Town history, and just as impressive was her love of architecture. Our friend lives in Cape Town and he also said he learned so much. Great tour with a warm hearted women. When we asked I'd she would accept a tip for her excellent services, she told us to give that money to a local church charity. Enough said!

Perfect tour for first time visitor. On the day we went on the tour it was just Ursula, my friend, and I. She does a great job of pointing out history that rests in plain sight, things you would not have noticed without her expertise. The walk through Bo-Kaap and her depth of knowledge were impressive. For a first time visitor, it's a good intro with a lovely guide.

The hidden gems of Cape Town. Yesterday I went on a great walking tour of Cape Town with Ursula and this is an experience that you shouldn't miss. Ursula guides in English and German and she has a wonderful way of bringing the city's history to life. I particularly enjoyed discovering the architectural variety of the downtown area and the rich history of the Bo-Kaap.

Great walking tour of cape Town. Our guide Ursula gave us a wonderful walking tour of Cape Town. The tour was recommended by a friend that has done it previously. Ursula is very knowledgeable, and she delivers in a fresh manner, making you feel that the tour has been designed specially for you. She is a very special lady. Thank you Ursula. Alicia

Must do: Walking tour through the City Bowl. We were on this very interesting tour through the city bowl of Cape Town with Ursula Stevens. She knows the city very well and has shown us many places we would have never seen alone. Highly recommended for everyone that visits Caoe Town - also available in german with Ursula.

Very worthwhile. Our guide was Ursula. Extremely knowledgeable and passionate about making sure you see everything. The nice thing about this is that you really get to see things that you would not see in a car. Thank you Ursula for a very interesting morning.

A lifetime of Cape Town history - highly recommended.. Your guide will be Ursula Stevens who has been taking these tours since the 1980s. In addition to the 3 hour tours she has also written books about Cape Town and it's surrounding area and is ideally placed to provide an informative, enlightened and enjoyable tour.Your journey will include the centre of Cape Town, Company Gardens, St George Cathedral Boo Kap and much much more. Our party of 10 was equally split between English and German speakers and Ursula switched between both languages effortlessly. We loved the experience and picked up a lot of new points that have been missed during our previous four stays in Cape Town. In our view the Cape Town Tourism Agency should put Ursula forward as a National Treasure.

Fantastic walking tour. Our guide, Ursula Stevens, was the most knowledgeable, engaging guide. We were lucky enough to have her to ourselves as we strolled through Cape Town centre learning and enjoying places we'd never have found for ourselves. She likes people to see the "living city" as well as landmarks and we certainly did that! Found out so much more than any guide book - although you could read one of hers! Fabulous tour. Even though at the end of our time here, we shall be back and able to explore more areas now we know! Thank you Ursula.

Ursula is a terrific guide. We have just enjoyed a 2.5 hour walking tour through Cape Town with Ursula Stevens from Wanderlust. Very knowledgeable, interesting, easy to understand and historically factual. I highly recommended this tour.

Terrific tour. This 2 hour walking tour with an incredibly knowledgable and engaging local guide was a highlight of our trip. Our time with Ursela was invaluable as we were able to walk around the center city of Cape Town learning about its history, architecture, people and much more. If we has been walking around on our own we would have missed so much and would not have been comfortable navagating the busy traffic. She limits the size of the group (we only had 6). We could hear well and had ample opportunity for questions. Ursula could charge doube for this trip and it would be a bargain. The bookstore where we met was also charming with many great books, cards..both in German and English.

Walking tour of Cape Town with Wolfgang!. I was in Cape town last weekend with my wife and she put up with my fetish to do a walking tour of Cape Town. While I have been there many times on business I have not had the opportunity to do a walking tour. We signed up for Wanderlust and got Wolfgang, he was terrific. His background was in languages at one of the local universities but his local knowledge in the quirky architecture and folklore of Cape Town was excellent. My favorite piece of the tour was a piece of plaster work over the old slave detention center where he explained that the sculptor was not very happy with the British and decided to have some fun. He depicted the lion as a feeble sort an the Unicorn looking back towards the lion thinking this guy is not going to give me any grief! I have probably messed up the story but go visit with Wolfgang and he will give you the real story.

Fabulous way to learn about architecture & local history!!. Ursula is an author on local history in Cape Town & it is real treat to walk the streets with her as she opens your eyes. Great value for money. It also helped to really orientate us around the city.

Walking Encyclopeadia. How wonderful to have the person that has written so many books about the city giving you the tour. This sort of opportunity does not come by often. Ursula has extensive knowledge of all things Cape Town, she speaks a number of languages and she is simply fantastic with children. She also has a warm welcoming nature so that you immediately connect with her. I can highly recommend her tour.I must add though as wonderful as she is with children, I should not have dragged my kids with. It was simply too long for them, and then I was distracted from all the interesting information because they were no longer interested.

Wanderlust Cape Town on foot city walks. Ursula gave us an excellent tour of Cape Town followed by some of the Bo-Kaap. She gave us lots of information and the history and made it a very interesting tour.

Wolfgang was great!. We spent the morning with Wolfgang, who gave us a great tour, rich with history and general information. He pointed out many great places he recommended we visit on our own. We really appreciated all his good advice.

Wonderful tour with wonderful tour guide! . The walking tour with Ursula is a must do in Cape Town, especially if you are interested in the history of the city as well as learning more about the iconic areas and buildings. Ursula has such a vast and in depth knowledge of the history of the city. She took us to a few spots of the beaten path that we wouldn't have gone/even know about if we had been alone that went along way to helping us imagine how Cape Town was like in the past. We really enjoyed that. The tour is also great as it follows an order, you make a loop as you move around, so you not zigzagging all over the place. Ursula also recommends good places that we pass to return back to go into along the way which is fab as we found a lovely bakery where we had snack when the tour was over. Thanks Ursula for a lovely introduction to Cape Town!

Wow! Wow! Wow!. Thank you for an amazing tour Ursula! A must do in Cape Town both for foreigners and South Africans. Ursula is passionate and very knowledgeable and will take you on a fabulous guided tour of the mother city! We absolutely loved it - thank you!

If you like history, you must do this tour..... We had a wonderful 3 hour walking tour with Ursula through the heart of Cape Town. We had been in South Africa 2 weeks, but this tour connected all the dots on the history and people of the country. The depth of the guides knowledge and passion for the subject was outstanding.

Wonderful!!!!. Today we were lucky to be guided by Ursula at our first encounter with Capetown. A Great Way to Learn about Cape Town. We chose to take this tour on our first full day in Cape Town. It was a perfect way to get to know the city, its history and its residents. Recommended walk. We chose this walk as an orientation for our short stay in Cape Town. The historical background was very interesting.You often find that places you would walk past without a second thought are in fact steeped in history. Well worth it.

Amazing walking tour. I consider myself most fortunate to have had a guided walk around the city of Cape Town with this excellent knowledgable walking tour guide. Do not miss this!. When doing my research for our trip to Cape Town I came across Wanderlust and figured it would be a good way to at least get some basic orientation of the city. Excellent guided walking tour!. We discovered this tour randomly when we were at the Cape Town Tourism Center (which is also the starting point). Must do!. I have the pleasure of living in Cape Town for the last 6,5 years and consider myself almost to be Capetonian. A tour with Wanderlust is definetly a must and I'll recommend it to any visitor who asks me: what do I HAVE to do in Cape Town?

Insightful and fascinating introduction to Cape Town and SA. Thanks so much Wolfgang for such a interesting talk and walk! A must for your first few days in Cape Town. my husband and I booked the tour with Ursula by email from home in the UK. Awesome historic walk of Cape Town. I want to say thank you very much to Wolfgang! I was the only person who showed up and had the luxury to get a private tour. Great!. This was an informative and enjoyable tour. I am a South African and was very impressed with Ursula's knowledge - not only of Cape Town, but of South Africa as a whole. Informative. Great introduction to the city's history. Two and a half hours were just right. Ursula is clearly a passionate historian who has researched and written a lot about the history of Cape Town. Definitely recommend doing this.

Great school day!. We chose this walking tour based on the fantastic reviews, and Ursula met all our expectations. She was knowledgeable and kept the children's (ages 10-17yrs) attention throughout. Thank you Wolfgang!. I am participating a congress in Cape Town and had no time at all to get familiar with the city before my arrival. Fantastic tour. Most worthwhile tour. Ursula was a great, knowledgeable guide. The tour was a gentle walk that covered a great deal of the city. The underground city and markets were really different than we have at home. It was great!

Great Tour with a Great Lady!. Ursula knows her stuff! This a great tour to kick off your trip to Cape Town. Unreliable. We turned up at the Cape Town Tourism Center at 10am sharp on a Saturday only to be told that the guide had left 5 mins before the starting time of the tour.
